author: Michael Roddan
title: Economic growth 'vulnerable': Westpac
text:
Westpac is confident the Reserve Bank will not make a cut to interest rates when it meets in a fortnight, despite new research from the bank showing the likely pace of growth to be below trend.
The Westpac-Melbourne Institute Leading Index, which indicates the likely pace of economic activity three to nine months into the future, increased from negative 1.14 per cent in August to negative 0.35 per cent in September.
Growth in the index has now been below trend for the last five months, Westpac chief economist Bill Evans said.
"Growth looks a little vulnerable based on this current run of below trend growth rates for the Leading Index," Mr Evans said.
Over the last six months the six month annualised growth rate in the Leading Index has slowed from being 0.16 per cent above trend to 0.35 per cent below trend.
Westpac said it expects the RBA, which meets on November 3, to hold off from cutting rates.
"The minutes from the October board meeting emphasised that the bank is comfortable with the outlook for the labour market and the apparent slowing in the housing market," Mr Evans said.
"However the board did highlight the importance of the global outlook and seems to be more downbeat on China," he said.
Mr Evans said a rate cut in early next year would require the RBA to be forecasting growth in 2016 to be 2.5 per cent or less without a policy response.
The Leading Index is signalling lower growth outlook in the first half of next year than Westpac's 2.75 per cent forecast, while the RBA is currently expecting a 3 per cent growth rate.
"The risks to our current view that rates will remain on hold for the remainder of 2015 and 2016 are to the downside," Mr Evans said.
